title: How to Clean Ink off the Inside of a Dryer

steps.title: Wipe off ink with rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: Wipe off ink with rubbing alcohol. [1] X Expert Source Bridgett Price House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 23 May 2019. Take a soft cloth and dampen it with rubbing alcohol. Gently blot the ink. It should come out fairly easily. [2] X Research source If there is more than one ink stain in the dryer, use a separate cloth for each section. It is important to blot the stain instead of rubbing it. [3] X Expert Source Bridgett Price House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 23 May 2019.

steps.title: Use magic eraser.
steps.content: Use magic eraser. Magic eraser is an eraser sold by Mr. Clean that helps remove stubborn stains from various surfaces. Using magic eraser is simple. You simply dampen the eraser and gently swab it over the ink stain to remove the unwanted stain. [4] X Research source If the stain is a little tough to get out, do not hesitate to scrub a little harder to remove it.

steps.title: Try a bug spray.
steps.content: Try a bug spray. Commercial bug spray can actually help remove ink stains. The brand Off works particularly well at eliminating ink stains. All you have to do is spray the repellent directly on the stain and proceed to wipe it away using paper towels. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Run bleach-soaked towels through a dry cycle.
steps.content: Run bleach-soaked towels through a dry cycle. After using any cleaning method described above, you should always run bleach-soaked towels through a dry cycle to ensure any lingering stains are removed. Soak some old towels in bleach. Wring the towels out so they're not dripping wet and place them in the dryer. Run them through a complete cycle. [6] X Research source If you still notice ink stains in the dryer, run them through another cycle. Always wear gloves when handling bleach.

steps.title: Try vegetable shortening.
steps.content: Try vegetable shortening. Let the dryer run empty for a few minutes. Smear plain vegetable shortening onto the ink. Let it sit on a few minutes before wiping off the shortening. If successful, the ink should come off as well.

steps.title: Use nail polish remover.
steps.content: Use nail polish remover. If you have any nail polish remover, rub it into the stain with a soft cloth or rag. If you apply a little pressure, the ink should eventually come off.

steps.title: Try a strong shampoo.
steps.content: Try a strong shampoo. If you have a strong shampoo on hand, you can rub this into the ink to remove it. This works best with a shampoo labeled as full-strength.

steps.title: Run bleach-soaked towels through the dryer.
steps.content: Run bleach-soaked towels through the dryer. With household products, it's important ensure any stains are completely removed. Soak a few old towels with bleach. Wring them out to make sure they're not dripping wet and then toss them in the dryer. Run a full cycle to finish the cleaning process. [7] X Research source Repeat if necessary. Make sure to wear gloves when handling bleach.

steps.title: Check with the manufacturer.
steps.content: Check with the manufacturer. Before attempting to treat ink stains, check manufacturing instructions or call the manufacturer. You want to make sure that the product you're using is safe for your dryer. The manufacturer may also have specific tips for getting ink out of your brand of dryer.

steps.title: Unplug the dryer before cleaning.
steps.content: Unplug the dryer before cleaning. It's dangerous to clean the dryer when it's plugged in. Before applying any cleaning product to the drum, unplug your dryer from the wall. You can plug it back in before adding the bleach soaked towels to complete the cleaning process.

steps.title: Be careful not to smear the ink.
steps.content: Be careful not to smear the ink. Always use separate rags to clean different ink stains in your dryer. If you simply wipe the same rag around in your dryer, this can result in you smearing the stain around. [8] X Research source
